reviewText: This movie was a little better than I was expecting. It was very funny and very dirty. Cameron Diaz is the best bad teacher ever. She cusses at her students, mocks them, drinks in her class, and does drugs. At the start of the new school year, Elizabeth meets a new teacher named Scott. She tries to flirt with him, but he just got out of a bad relationship and just wants to be friends. She begins to embezzle from the school so she can have breast surgery. Another snoopy teacher named Amy Squirrel competes against Elizabeth and tries to prove she is stealing money. I highly recommend BAD TEACHER!!!

A reluctant teacher loses her wealthy fianc' and thus has to return to the job she hates. Desiring breast implants, she pursues the bonus awarded to the teacher whose class has the highest test scores. Along the way she is pursed by a gym teacher, tries to connect with a rich substitute, and finds a rival in a fellow teacher, the funniest and most well-developed character in the film. This is a movie that I found funny and refreshing, in that it is not laced with vulgarities and profanity throughout. This is a movie that provides laughs while not seeking the lowest common denominator. A pleasant surprise.

R-rated comedies are really starting to all feel exactly the same. The same argument can more than likely be made for any genre, but R-rated comedies seem to be the guiltiest of mimicking that one gem in its arsenal that did well a few years ago. Avatar is probably one of the reasons that 75% of movies are offered in the 3D format, nearly every superhero film does well thanks to comic book fans, and Pixar and Dreamworks pretty much rule the animated film market. When it comes to adult comedies, we have the likes of The Hangover and Judd Apatow films to blame for their success and nearly every R-rated comedy since has either felt like it's been marketed towards fans of those films or copies their formula entirely. That's one of the reasons Bad Teacher isn't able to achieve being more than a decent comedy; it's never really able to walk along on its own and piggybacks on other well known films and TV shows to try and get a laugh.

Do any of you reading this watch "South Park"? Did you ever see the episode where Mr. Garrison decides that he wants to be a man again? While Garrison is off dealing with that, Cartman becomes the teacher. He lets all the kids cheat on the test, they all test higher than the school ever has in the past, and he's sent to one of the most troubled schools in the county to try and help the students there. He disguises himself as Mr. Cartmanez (How do I reach these keeeeeeds?!) and teaches them how to cheat to succeed. Bad Teacher almost channels this story verbatim. Elisabeth Halsey (Cameron Diaz) disguises herself to meet and seduce the man who's in charge of guiding the state exams. Once she knows what's on the test, she teaches her students only what's on the test so that she can receive the $5700 bonus. Meanwhile the rest of the film feels like a watered down version of Bad Santa if it was centered on a woman and was set in a middle school instead of a mall. Ms. Halsey hates teaching and mostly has her class sit through movies daily since she's off drinking every night, smoking weed in her car, and generally just not giving a crap about any of her students or the faculty she's surrounded by.

The cast is able to play off of each other pretty well. Cameron Diaz does seemingly slide into the bad teacher role with ease and her on screen chemistry with Justin Timberlake is more than likely due to their former relationship, but results in a few memorable scenes in the end. Lucy Punch is so high strung, energetic, and perky that you basically just want to knock her down and punch her in the face repeatedly just to get her to shut up by the time the movie is over, so I guess that means she played the role of Amy Squirrel to perfection. "The Office"'s Phyllis Smith is pretty much the same character she is on the show with just a little more R-rated content added to her resume. The highlights of the cast have to be Jason Segel and Justin Timberlake though. Segel is the one guy in the movie that'll probably make you snicker the loudest while Timberlake has a few scenes (one in particular) that is almost really funny with Cameron Diaz. The song he sings is so ridiculous that you can't help but laugh. Whoever that kid was that kept giving Amy Squirrel that look of open mouthed disbelief in her classroom was brilliant, as well.

The storyline really snowballs into absurdity as the movie progresses though. You're basically rooting for the villain the entire movie. A selfish individual who puts herself before everyone somehow gets away with basically being a drunken whore, who breaks the law a countless number of times, treats her students and co-workers like garbage, and keeps her job without learning a lesson throughout the entire process. It comes off like she has to settle for less by the time it's all said and done. It's pretty crazy.

Bad Teacher is a fairly mediocre adult comedy. It tries to reel in viewers with its very open relationship with the raunchiness featured in the film, but it all feels really tame in the end and isn't nearly as over the top as The Hangover Part II or even Your Highness. The problem is there isn't much that separates Bad Teacher from other R-rated comedies out there. It feels very similar and run of the mill. The movie would probably be a waste of time if it wasn't for Jason Segel, Justin Timberlake, and the staring kid in Amy Squirrel's class. While Bad Teacher is amusing at times, it isn't outrageously laugh out loud funny and mostly feels like a rehash of something you've already seen.

The title Bad Teacher automatically brings to mind Bad Santa, another raunchy R-rated comedy from years past. The two films are unrelated and completely different in tone, but worthy of comparison as they both take the concept of someone who works around children and make them into despicable characters. The difference is that Billy Bob Thornton's Santa was an offensive, outrageous alcoholic who used the Santa Clause-guise as a way to rob shopping malls; Cameron Diaz's Elizabeth Halsey is just a lazy, superficial, and yes, bad teacher. It's been 13 years since Diaz starred in the mother of raunchy R-rated comedies There's Something About Mary and it's nice to see her return to this comedic setting where she seems most comfortable. I would've liked seeing her tackle a dark character, but the movie plays it safe with a light tone. Diaz is a capable comedic actress and she plays this role with great relish, but she's trapped in an uninspired story with a concept that's never fully realized and suffers as a result.

Elizabeth Halsey is a bored middle school teacher leaving her job behind to marry a rich man who will take care of her. The day she leaves her job, her fiance leaves her forcing her to return to work. Marrying a rich man who will take care of her seems to be her only goal, while her only activities seem to be drinking, getting high, and insulting anyone she can. She's poor, lives with a man she met on Craigslist, and her only friend seems to be her quiet, passive, and older co-worker Lynn (Phyllis Smith). At work, she usually arrives with a hangover and sleeps at her desk while showing movies to her class. This becomes a problem when dedicated teacher Amy Squirrel (Lucy Punch), who is across the hall from Elizabeth, takes notice. While shunning the advances of the gym teacher Russell (Jason Segel), Elizabeth fantasizes about getting plastic surgery to attract the type of man she's looking for and sets her eye on the new substitute Scott Delacorte (Justin Timberlake). With a yearly bonus offered to teachers with the highest testing students, Elizabeth sees a way to exploit her job for her own gain.

Diaz is a natural comedic talent and she has a lot of fun with this role which, despite her efforts, is just not meaty enough. Elizabeth is vulgar, despicable, rude, and politically incorrect and so was Thornton in Bad Santa. The difference was that you could empathize with Thornton and there was an underlying theme of redemption that gave his depravity a purpose. You'll recall also that he was a thief who dressed as Santa to rob shopping malls. Why is Elizabeth a teacher? There is no reason besides the convenience of the plot. It's hard to accept that this woman actually worked through four years of college to get to this point. Since the writers offer no theme of redemption and no reason for Elizabeth being a teacher, there's ultimately no purpose for her being the vulgar character she is. It's vulgarity for vulgarity's sake. She's just an unlikable character; not unlikable in the sense that I didn't like her, but in the sense that you see no reason for the characters in the film to like her and, by the end, when she has ruined innocent people's lives for her own selfish gain, you're left with no one to root for. This hurts the film.

Much of the cast does a fine job and I liked the characters, but I wished they were allowed to roam in a more natural comic setting. Diaz is the driving force behind the movie and proves that she can still carry a decent comedy, but her comedy is frequently upstaged by the minor characters. Her character isn't because, while far from three-dimensional, she serves a purpose in every scene she's in. The minor characters are not so much characters as they are excuses, simply appearing at the convenience of the writers, but some of their bits work. Kirk (Eric Stonestreet), the roommate, scores laughs in all four or so of his scenes but is underutilized. Smith is a bit of a scene-stealer and her character is one of the few examples of consistent writing present. Lynn is so awkwardly unsure of herself, so passive, one of those teachers who is no different out of the classroom. I was waiting for the moment where she would get drunk or high and become out of control. When she finally does get high, the credibility of her character is not betrayed. Furthermore, her lines of insecure agreement with Diaz's vulgar affirmations are understated and all the more amusing. My favorite character is Jason Segel's gym teacher Russell, also tragically underused. Segel is one of those actors that can take a simple phrase and make it amusing with his delivery and even when spewing throwaway lines he's the most likable, memorable character. Amy Squirrel is the only character that has a purpose in the film besides selfishness and her character contrasts well with Elizabeth, but the writing ultimately fails her. Punch's performance is intentionally over-the-top from the beginning, but she bubbles over as the film progresses and seems borderline psychotic. She plays Amy as one of those peppy teachers who are so into their job that some students shake their heads in disbelief. Amy is annoying, but she's not a bad person and yet the film expects us to see her as the villain and be pleased when things go wrong for her. It doesn't work.

You'll see other familiar faces, notably John Michael Higgins as the dolphin-obsessed principal and Thomas Lennon, who both score laughs. The weakest link in the cast, I'm sorry to say, is poor Justin Timberlake, so good in last year's The Social Network and so stiff here. I would have campaigned for Timberlake to receive an Oscar nod last year, so I'm not sure what happened. Granted, Scott is just an air-headed, nave substitute teacher but Timberlake looks so uncomfortable and he delivers his lines so unconvincingly it sounds like he's reading from cue cards. Maybe he felt awkward working with Diaz, his real-life former girlfriend which would explain why they have absolutely no chemistry in the film. It's not important for their characters to have chemistry but in their scenes together Diaz is convincingly in character while Timberlake seems like a bewildered extra who has wandered onto the set. Segel and Diaz meanwhile have a good rapport, but it's not exactly chemistry as I didn't buy that they'd end up together because of Elizabeth's attitude and demeanor, but they do work well together in a scene.

The writers that I've blamed for much of the film's failure are Gene Stupnitsky and Lee Eisenberg, who had a concept that could have been very funny and carried it out in a very by-the-numbers fashion. When the script reaches the point where Elizabeth and Amy are going back-and-forth trying to one-up each other in who can screw the other over more, it just feels generic and I suspect the two ran out of ideas. The script is passable, funny at times, and I applaud the way they portray the children without the stereotypical cliques, but some of the jokes are of poor quality and feel forced, while sometimes the bits of "stupid humor" just become "stupid" humor. The dry-humping scene is inexplicable. It may have seemed like a funny idea to the writers, but their execution of it and the translation of it from page to screen doesn't work. Quite frankly, some of the writing is really bad.

Bad Teacher could have benefited from a darker tone or at least some consistency. It's R-rated but it feels very PG-13 aside from the frequent swearing. I didn't dislike the movie and I found the hour and a half running time passed by quickly enough. I even admit I laughed several times. It's a light-hearted, but mean-spirited film that moves unassumingly to a predictable (and contrived) conclusion. This movie wasn't meant to change the world, there are moments that are hit and moments that are miss. I remember one scene of the movie making me laugh harder than all the others for a good few seconds, but I have no recollection of the scene it was. Bad Teacher is not a bad movie; it's just not a particularly memorable one.

GRADE: C+

BadTeacher is one of the funniest movies I have ever seen, and I could see it becoming a cult  classic, because it is so outrageous, and quotable. I don't want to get into a long review, just make this short and sweet. This is an outrageous comedy as I said before. So don't get all worked up when things are unrealistic. The supporting cast is strong. Well cast movie. All the characters are funny in their own way. I found myself rooting for Elizabeth (Cameron Diaz) because as bad as she is, in her own way, her nemesis, fellow teacher Amy Squirrel (Lucy Punch) is quite hateful to Elizabeth just for the sake of being mean, and she thinks she is GOD'S GIFT TO TEACHING, FULL OF HERSELF.  The main plot of the movie, and what moves things along, is Elizabeth is trying to get enough money for breast augmentation and will stop at nothing. She does have one redeeming quality and you might not realize until the end of the movie. She is good at counseling people in her own abrupt way, whether it be a student in love with a girl that hates him: "look, I can't keep sugar coating this for you", and she lays it on the line, and encouraging Lynn her fellow teacher to have the courage to talk to some cowboys in a bar.  She does seem to grow up a little in the movie, but it's a WILD RIDE GETTING THERE!!!  Also, this is one of those movies, the more you watch it, the funnier it is. So much for short and sweet! Oh, and I must make special mention of the principal,played by John Michael Higgins, what an excellent comedic actor. He has been in  the mockumentaries of Christopher Guest. which are improv, Two of my faves "Best in Show" and "A Mighty Wind"

I absolutely hated this movie, which is surprising, because I actually really enjoy movies of this kind. I loved Superbad, Knocked Up, Guidance and Young Adult, but this was total garbage. I didn't really have any expectations out of it going in other than hoping that it would be funny,  but it could not even do that.

I think it is because  the character of Cameron Diaz, Elizabeth Halsey, has no redeeming qualities about her whatsoever. She is lazy, mean, rude and manipulative and a nightmare teacher. But not in a cool, endearing way like Pat Mills in Guidance, who smokes pot and drinks alcohol with his students, but in this annoyingly detestable way.

Where you hope the Bad Teacher to be someone who pushes the boundaries of what's decent in a civilized society,  you find someone who is a callous, stuck-up bi_ch whose class syllabus consists of showing movies while she takes a nap. She is a gold-digger who only dates rich people and who steals money from the school car wash to buy breast implants so she can find a new man to take care of her.  In fact, her main goal in life is to earn or steal enough money to get herself ready so she can find a rich husband. She is rude, mean and incredibly unpleasant, and - given what I have read about Cameron Diaz in real life and how she treats her fans - I am not even sure she is acting.

The thing is, no matter how screwed up and a loser a character is, no matter how self-deprecating and damaged, he or she does have to have some redeemable qualities. Or, if they dont, like in Young Adult, then at least not try to pass that irredeemability up as comedy.

Bad Teacher failes on both accounts. There is nothing redeemable about her - in fact, the character doesnt even have an arc and there is nothing funny about this movie  You cannot get behind her even one bit and even if you tried.

In Young Adult, Charlize Theron managed to create a character you are invested in - or at least intrigued by  enough to want to stick around and find out more.  There was something very real, tragic and sober in the way Theron played Mavis Gray, the young adult writer who, as the film progresses, is stripped down to something so ugly, unappealing, hopeless, and, in some uncomfortable ways, a little relatable. She is never glorified as being cool or maybe misunderstood. Unlike Bad Teacher that seems so desperate in its attempt to look cool  - and equally blinded by that desire - that it missed the mark by a long shot.

In Young Adult,  you stand behind Theron's character her because you feel sorry for her. Because she reaches rock bottom and still doesn't learn her lesson, so to speak. Cameron Diaz's character, on the other hand, is just a boring, stuck-up c)nt you are rooting for to fail no matter what.  So in a way I do recommend watching this movie, if for nothing then to see just how truly bad and unfunny it really is.

Bad Teacher takes place in modern day schools. Elizabeth Halsey, a mid-20s teacher is a great example of what a teacher should NOT be, at the beginning. Ms. Halsey, having just been broken up with by her fianc, goes to work as a teacher, as this is all she has a degree in. She is lazy, plays only movies, does not interact with students, and sleeps through most of the school day. She works for the paycheck, as she needs it now that her fianc left her. However, as the movie plays out, Ms. Halsey becomes more sentimental towards her students and at the end eventually ends up being the schools guidance counselor. Although I feel as if this movie is completely for entertainment, it has some real and relatable aspects to it. Though Ms. Halsey is not an ideal teacher, there are characters in the film that are. Amy Squirrel, for example, is a very engaged teacher. She relates to the students, has fun, and teaches passionately. She even uses a goofy voice that engages the students and makes them laugh. Secondly, I believe that the students in this movie are relatable to modern day students. Some are concerned about their grades, some are bullies, and others are outsiders. There are noticeable cliques and groups. This movie portrays what it is like for students growing up and going to school in a public school system. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie, comedy and all. I would recommend it and suggest that you look deep into what it the movies objective is. It has a number of underlying lessons about things such as bullying, teaching, how to treat students/teachers, etc. I believe it shows you good examples of what you should and should not do as a teacher.

Bad Teacher
 Bad Teacher immediately reminds us of Bad Santa, another alleged comedy of a few years past.  Both of them have as a premise a horrible human being who occupies a position of trust in society and uses said position ruthlessly to his or her own advantage.  Neither film lives up to the claim to be a comedy.  Bad Teacher ill uses the talents of star Cameron Diaz.  Diaz not only can stand up to any star currently working in the comedy realm but can deliver a fine dramatic performance as well.  In this one she plays a lying, conniving, selfish, booze and drug abusing user of people for her own advancement.  I found little funny with her character, in fact, quite the opposite.  She seemed to me reptilian and aphotic, cold, heartless and without light.  No wonder the writers had a hard time coming up with things to make us laugh.
 Let me say that Diaz does indeed sell the role.  We believe that she is exactly what the writers mean for her to be.  This speaks well for her as an actress if not for the comic writing chops of the scripters.  Jason Segel, as the school gym teacher who finds the flawed, sexy new teacher Diaz fascinating, plays a sharp, intuitive guy who has both patience and persistence.  The movie works through the bad personality traits of the Diaz character, balancing them against the good personality traits of the other characters.
 Justin Timberlake, at one time the real life love interest of Miss Diaz, appears as the prey of the focused gold digging teacher.  This is another role where Timberlake surprises me.  Silly me, I still think of him as the boy band singer that he once was.  At this stage of his life, he has become a perfectly respectable actor.  He is spot on here as the good natured simpleton who might well fall into the web of Diazs black-widow-like schemes.
 Also look for Molly Shannon from Saturday Night Live in a small role.  Noah Munck, the kid who counts his lawn mowing money with such vigor in the TruGreen TV commercials, also appears.  Lucy Punch plays the absurdly named teacher Amy Squirrel, a rival of Diaz for the affections of the dim but sweet educator played by Timberlake.
 The movie isn't funny, but it does work as a kind of transformational tale.  Just as the coward finds his courage in The Red Badge of Courage, so the relentlessly wicked Diaz finds the true path to goodness.  Fellow teacher Amy Squirrel (Lucy Punch) reverses directions, moving from a goody goody to the dark side.
 Director Jake Kasdan also holds the responsibility for the also not funny and worse in Hollywood, the not profitable Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story.  Maybe we should hope he directs an adventure flick or a drama in the future.  Comedy is not his forte.
 This film rates an average three saw blades, but not as a comedy.  The acting of the major players holds this movies only redemption.  Director Kasdan will see this $19 million effort come into the black, for which he should give thanks to Segel, Diaz and Timberlake.  It is rated R for raunchy language and adult situations (but no naked people-only photos of same.)  It runs an also average 92 minutes.

The 2011 comedy BAD TEACHER came out as America's war on teachers was in full force.  Okay, by "America" I mean the moneyed interests that control much of the discourse force-fed to the public via corporate media, people who'd love to take your tax dollars and, in this instance, use them for their private charter schools that may not necessarily admit your children.

With all that in mind, I wondered if BAD TEACHER would condemn those who teach in public schools but, thankfully, this pleasantly surprising farce ignores that witch hunt.  In fact, starting with the song that opens the film, the forgotten, albeit very good song by Rockpile, "Teacher, Teacher," suddenly I realized I was in for a less-than-predictable comedy.  Less imaginative filmmakers would have chosen Chuck Berry's "School Days," Alice Cooper's "School's Out," or some other selection about school that everyone's heard a thousand times.

BAD TEACHER proves very funny, as opposed to stupid, unlike too many movies aimed at young adults. Cameron Diaz looks no fewer than ten years too old for the part, but she does such a great job I, for one, suspended disbelief.

As I write this in 2014, the war against public school teachers rages on.  Ignore the charter school gang's lies and pay attention to something much more worth your while, Cameron Diaz in BAD TEACHER.

Since most people already summarized the plot, I'll only give a brief synopsis: Elizabeth Halsey is a gold-digging middle school teacher who is about to retire and marry her fiance. After he dumps her, she reluctantly goes back to teaching. She is abusive and apathetic towards the students. She also abuses drugs and alcohol. There is a love triangle between Elizabeth, another teacher (Amy Squirrel, played by Lucy Punch, who is MUCH more attractive than Cameron Diaz), and a wealthy substitute teacher (played by Justin Timberlake). The school's gym teacher is attracted to Elizabeth, but she is not interested in him.

Elizabeth wants to get a breast augmentation (how classy) so she plans to embezzle the money from the 7th grade class car wash. The highlight of the movie was seeing Cameron Diaz in a wet t-shirt and short shorts. Elizabeth later learned that the teacher of the class with the highest state test scores would receive a bonus so she tried to adopt a more draconian approach to teaching, but that didn't work. She then stole the answers to the exam.

Elizabeth won the bonus. However, Amy suspected that she cheated. Meanwhile, on a school trip, Elizabeth talked to one of her male students who had a crush on a shallow female student. This caused Elizabeth to reflect on her own actions. Back at the school, Amy tried to get the janitor to open Elizabeth's sealed drawer in order to prove that she had the answers. However, Elizabeth told the principal that some of the teachers in the school were doing drugs and drinking alcohol on the job. When they found Elizabeth's drugs and liquor bottles in Elizabeth's desk (that was switched), Amy was transferred to the worst school in the district. In the next school year, Elizabeth became a guidance counselor and started a relationship with the gym teacher.

These are middle school kids and yes, she's as raunchy with them as with the adults. She's an alcoholic and a drug addict who keeps a large stash of drugs in her classroom desk and in her car. Why Diaz, Timberlake and Segel agreed to do this movie I'll never know. There must have been a lot of money in the budget for their salaries.

Those of you who disagree with me and say I'm just a prude who doesn't like raunch, fugetaboutit, because I do enjoy raunch and I already told you I like American Pie and Horrible Bosses. When "Animal House" (1978) and "Porky's" (1982) burst onto the cinematic scene, they ushered in the new genre of the R-rated comedy, a style of film so narrow that attempting to release an entertaining movie can be as challenging as a perfect score on the SAT's.  Unfortunately, "Bad Teacher" barely achieves a passing grade.

The film is cast well: Cameron Diaz plays Elizabeth Halsey, a golddigger who decides that teaching is an easy way to bide her time (summers off, supposedly short work days) while searching for a rich man to support her extravagant habits for the rest of her life.  She meets Justin Timberlake, who plays a rich school substitute that Diaz believes to fit her bill, but only after she can purchase breast implants. With her sights set on her male conquest, she moves in for the kill, in competition with a nauseatingly over-enthusiastic colleague, played to the hilt by "Dinner for Schmucks'" Lucy Punch, who provides ample perseverance for Timberlake's affection.

Though the actors understand their comedy, the plot is mundane.  That Diaz distorts going through the motions of responsibility within the school community (chaperoning a car wash dressed in Daisy Dukes, scheming to cheat on a standardized test to acquire the school bonus for the top score) to acquire the funds for her surgery comes across as ridiculous and makes one want to expel her for the remainder of the school year. By the time she realizes the predictable error of her ways, we don't care.  Only Jason Segel, as the gym teacher who sees through the transparent faade of Diaz's schemes, appears as a likeable character within this dimwitted academic institution.  Give "Bad Teacher" a C-;  it doesn't fail, but you won't consult it for any help with your homework.

In other words, it isn't a gross-out, genitalia-laden, bodily functions-heavy, everyone-act-like-a-thirteen-year-old pile of audience insulting stupidity. It does have a few unnecessary shots, but those are quick one-offs that, while totally unnecessary, don't torpedo things completely. The comedy is certainly crude, but at least they go for acerbic instead of infantile. Given how many puerile offerings are being made, I'm taking what I can get.

There's a host of vaguely familiar actors, but the best effort comes from the dead panning Jason Segel, doing his best Bill Murray circa the mid-80s as the P.E. teacher. Justin Timberlake never fully convinces me as the substitute the two main female characters vie for, maybe because he seems to be trying so hard in every role I've seen him perform.  Then there's Cameron Diaz as the main lead, playing against her normal cutesy characters as a slutty, ill-mannered, gold digging party girl who incredulously happens to be a public school teacher. The problem is that Cameron Diaz isn't Billy Bob Thornton so it was hard to buy her as the same kind of foul-mouthed loser he plays with such ease.

Bad Teacher isn't a horrible movie, although it will probably offend those hand-wringing, paranoid, Helen Lovejoy-types who find any movie in which children are exposed to anything adult as the first steps on the road to the apocalypse. If you aren't one of those people, however, you might find some laughs along the way. From a teacher's perspective, there were some funny moments (the grading of papers, overzealous teachers, parent orientation), but the story has a lot of holes that simply don't make sense or stretch credulity too far, and thus prevent the movie from ever getting off the ground.

Bad Teacher is tepidly recommended if you can preview it for free before buying.  2.5 stars.

This is a one-joke premise, funny in itself as an idea, but it takes a good script to turn into a reasonable feature film. To do so, writers Lee Eisenberg and Gene Stupnitsky somehow thought it good to make our heroine shallow and cunning. Elizabeth wants money for breast-implant surgery to impress Scott, so what would she do? Car wash! When she learns about a $5,700 bonus awarded to the teacher of the highest-performing class, what would she do? Something illegal, of course.

I liked none of the characters in the film (including Jason Segel's teacher who keeps yelling), but that is not really a problem. Some comedy characters are not really likable persons themselves (remember Mr. Bean). The real problem is, unlike in better comedies, most jokes are not as funny as the filmmakers think, dependent on the concept of "bad teacher."

And those gags are not just lame; they are mostly like watching a cruel and nasty prank being played on an unsuspecting by-passer. Mixing "School of Rock" and "Bad Santa" is not a bad idea, but it needs not only jokes, but storytelling skills and consistent characters of these movies.

As a comedy the movie does contain some genuine laugh-out-loud moments. However, anyone who was not terribly impressed with the commercials should be forewarned that the film is equally unimpressive. We begin with Elizabeth Halsey (Cameron Diaz,) a beauty who is beginning to feel her youth slipping away, and who attempts to fill the void in her life through drugs and shopping. Teaching was a profession which she fell into more so than anything, and consequently her attitude toward education is one of apathy. After a rocky beginning (her husband and his mother kick Elizabeth out of the house) she finds herself trading a sports car for a rice burner, as she drive drives back to JAMS (John Adams Middle School,) where, ironically enough, she had quit teaching three months before, having only been there for a year. Needless to say, her return to JAMS is not exactly thrilling to Elizabeth. She begins showing random movies which have class room scenes but which contain no educational qualities; all the while she is slumped on the side of her desk sleeping or using marijuana, or gazing with lusty eyes at the enlarged breasts of a supermodel. She herself, by the way, is squeezing every penny in the hopes having the operation done on her, which includes almost embezzling money from the middle school car wash.

It doesn't take long for a zany teacher named Amy Squirrel to get on Elizabeth's bad side, with superficially cutesy but threatening comments like "I know that last year you skated by doing the who 'bare minimum thing...' but this year I just know we'll be more than across-the-hall-mates." One the one hand, Amy is a stereotypical Hollywood portrayed educator who uses touchy-freely talk to work out problems and help students. Being somewhat eccentric, however, she treats faculty in much the same way that she treats her students, a fact which Elizabeth, who is brisk and businesslike, quickly comes to resent. What's more, Amy has a dark side, and underneath her I-feel-your-pain sympathies is a fiercely competitive and somewhat mentally unhinged teacher. Curiously enough, despite their very different world views, the two have in common their strong will and ruthless, Machiavellian methods of making each other miserable and using every one else as pones to undermine each other. So when a substitute math teacher Scott Delacourte (Justin Timberlake) who also happens to come from a well-to-do family in the watch making business, a classic romance triangle forms and the two women try everything to win him over. Scott himself is an offbeat character, embodying certain feminine features which, when played by Timberlake, are both  amusing and down right disturbing. Additionally Scott is weak and easily swayed, thus allowing for plenty of manipulation by both Amy and Elizabeth. On the outside of the triangle is Russel Gettis (Jason Segel,) a gym teacher at JAMS who, despite his crude comments and stalker-esque behavior, actually has feelings for Elizabeth, as is later shown by the fact that he thinks her body is just fine and that she doesn't need the operation to make her look beautiful.

Elizabeth gets into plenty of sticky situations throughout the school year which will give the audience something to laugh about, including stealing Amy's theater class Little Orphan Annie wig and pretending to be a reporter to gain access to the forthcoming state scholastic tests (and getting a state official drunk,) speeding out of the school parking lot while blaring Black Sabbath, rubbing poison oak on an apple as a "gift" for Amy, and much more. Additionally, she wears, as Amy says "provacative beach ware," to the middle car wash, looking like one of the beauties posing for Sports Illustrated more than a teacher at a car wash. We also meet an assortment of other characters, including Elizabeth's odd roommate who she later uses to blackmail the aforementioned state official. There is also the JAMS principal, who has a special place in his heart (and office!) for all things dolphin, thus playing on the stereotype of the progressive, bleeding heart principal.

Yet, as with all somewhat substantive comedies, the movie has its heartfelt moments, too, echoing the same limited substance of the American Pie franchise in its both tender and serious moments. We see that there are times when Elizabeth feels a connection with some of her students, particularly near the end of the movie, in which we see that she isn't a bad apple after all, despite her shortcomings and bad choices in so many areas. In her own way, she brings her own brand of realism to the table, helping some of the kids re-assess themselves. One of her students, Sasha, is a people-pleaser whose parents pressure her and desire that she aspire to high political office. Though Elizabeth's advice that Sasha should look into massage therapy instead is a bit heavy-handed, uncalled for, and cynical, the scene demonstrates Elizabeth's sense regarding the differences between hopes and dreams on the one hand, and real prospects on the other. Another example in which demonstrates she is not altogether apathetic about her students is seen in her lecture to one of the boys who has had an unrequited and hopeless crush on a classmate, Chance. It is here, perhaps for the first time, that Elizabeth demonstrates a disgust for her own superficial attempts to land marriage and money with Scott. She sees in herself the egoism of Chance, and she admonishes the male student to look for someone who can really appreciate his sensitive soul and interest in poetry. Additionally, about halfway through the school year she learns of a scheme to make her breast augmentation dreams a reality, via the teacher's bonus competition which comes from student's getting the highest scores on the annual state test. In one of the more touching elements about this film, we see an ever so subtle shift in Elizabeth's priorities as her interest becomes one of actually educating students rather than merely going through the motions. A final showdown with Amy occurs, and there are plenty of laughs to be had with that alone.

But all and all the movie was not successful. The acting was a up to par as one can expect from comedies, and Cameron Diaz really played her role well. But as a whole, while the movie did contain some redeeming elements, most viewers will find the unorthodox behavior and pervasive foul language use of the teachers in front of their students, simply too much. There is a scene in which Elizabeth writes "stupid" on some papers, and while this will arouse laughter from some quarters, others will not be so amused. One final interesting aspect of the movie is that it is a parody in some ways of the American school system. Pperhaps well apart from the intentions of its creators, it shows that despite the cliche idea of teachers as nurturing, progressive, and altruistic, they are often regular people who gripe about going to the office, are self-interested, and look to break up the monotony in life by resorting to the very juvenile behavior they are thought to be above.

The overriding conceit at the heart of `Bad Teacher' is the idea that the audience will somehow look past the reprehensible moral bankruptcy at the core of the central character (played to perfection by Cameron Diaz) and root for her, because she's good looking and has a few memorable one-liners so all can be forgiven. The character Diaz plays so well is dishonest, greedy, lazy, irresponsible, rude, utterly self-serving and in every way despicable. She is educating your kids, folks, and her manipulative, blackmailing ways win out for her in the end. This is funny, OK?

The film gets two stars rather than one because, on a purely technical level, it works as a (very improbable) narrative. The storyline is coherent and the editing snappy, the actors give their all, the script does have its moments, it's watchable. But somehow it's hard to get past the overall message the film leaves you with: if you're a selfish, lying, morally bankrupt, pot-smoking, drunken, money-grubbing whore willing to blackmail and deceive all around you whilst having complete contempt for any kind of professional responsibility to your students and their futures, this is in some way admirable. Let me begin by saying that I'm not a fan of the latest craze in movie comedy. For some reason the success of one movie that featured extreme vulgarity (THE HANGOVER) has resulted in numerous movies being released that seem to think the funniest parts were due to the rudeness of the language or visuals used. The fact is the funny parts commented on those items or around them but they were never the funny parts. That being said is BAD TEACHER a funny movie? In short, yes.

Cameron Diaz stars as Elizabeth Halsey, a teacher with little to offer. She's just marking time until she gets married to a rich available husband. While this is supposed to be her last year, her engagement collapses and she returns the next. Looking for a solution she decides that the reason she can't catch a top notch available male is because her breasts aren't big enough. She opts for augmentation but can't afford it and thus the main idea behind the movie kicks in, her trying to find a way to make the money.

At the school an overachieving teacher is found across the hall from Elizabeth. Amy Squirrel (Lucy Punch) is that do gooder type person who is filled with all sorts of goofy sayings and feel good quotes. Yes, she's most obnoxious. And of course Elizabeth takes an immediate disliking to her.

Falling in between the two is new substitute teacher Scott Delacorte (Justin Timberlake) who happens to be the grandson of an expensive watch maker. The dollar signs flash and Elizabeth is ready to set her trap. Unfortunately for her Amy makes her move first and the competition is on.

While this is happening Elizabeth does her best to make it through each day failing to inspire or teach any student who happens to fall in her path. Instead she simply plugs in the TV and shows her class movies that involved teachers like STAND AND DELIVER and LEAN ON ME. When she discovers that the teacher who has the students with the highest grades in a state wide test wins a check for over $5,000 she makes the decision to start teaching and hope it works.

Complications and skullduggery come into play as well as a revenge seeking Amy. But along the way Elizabeth ends up helping some of her students. She helps them find their way through the terrible time known as Junior High. And she finds something more in herself as well. She also happens to unknowingly find someone else in the school's gym teacher Russell Gettis (Jason Segel). How it all ends makes for some funny moments.

So the story along with the numerous laughs interspersed throughout is the good part. What's the bad? If you were paid a quarter for every time the F bomb or vulgar word for breasts were uttered you would be able to fill a theater with patrons. For some reason Hollywood seems to think this makes it funnier. It doesn't and the shock value wore off on me back in Junior High when that sort of thing was funny. Granted there are occasion when the words can elicit some great laughs (think PLANES TRAINS AND AUTOMOBILES or George Carlin's famous piece on the 7 dirty words) but when its just tossed in over and over it becomes annoying.

Diaz does a decent job here but she needs to rely on more than her looks to get her through a movie. While watching her talk about trying to save up enough money for plastic surgery one can't help but wonder if she's had her face done and if so where did that cash come from? Timberlake is showing that he can actually act and do a good job in comedy and drama. A Segel is a wonder, offering a subtle portrayal here of a goofy yet loveable guy. His is the most realistic portrayal of the bunch. Punch shows that she has the chops to pull of some great comedic moments and is someone I'm looking forward to seeing again. After some great bit parts in some hilarious movies its nice to see her star rising.

All in all if you can get past the language barrier this movie is funny more often than not. But know ahead of time if you are easily offended then this is not the movie for you. For everyone else, sit back and have a laugh.

While the premise of a teacher who hates her students is definitely serviceable, I was annoyed by two things:

1.  In the movie, the teacher's supposedly brutal sense of humor was too soft.  She really should have been much crueler.  I think this is because the film was going for the wrong sense of humor.  It was going for the shock-joke nature of comedy, while it should have been aiming at a sardonic, ironic kind of humor.  I kept waiting for her to unload some nasty, soul-crushing comments on the students or other faculty, but instead she was just a paper tiger.

2.  While her character was well-sketched, she underwent a complete, unprovoked reversal at the very end that betrayed everything that had gone before.  Quite apart from the fact that that ending could be seen coming from a mile way, the movie hadn't "earned" it.  It felt abrupt, felt like they had just done it because her renouncing her big goal abruptly at the end of the movie and starting to love teaching was what was expected by the audience.  But the movie would have been tons more effective and memorable if she stuck it out through the end, got her plastic surgery, and then given everyone the finger at the end of the movie.  It would have been much truer to her character and the nature of the film in general.

In other words, ruined by a Hollywood ending.

First fact, I'm a teacher. Second fact, normally, as that teacher, I rip teacher movies to shreds because they are so unrealistic and, often, downright dishonest. Third, I had so much fun watching "Bad Teacher!" Finally, a movie about teaching that doesn't pretend to be realistic. In fact, the movie is not about a teacher, but about Cameron Diaz playing a teacher. There's a significant difference! And, as a big Cameron Diaz fan, I was delighted!

Director Jake Kasdan, going with the obvious stance of Diaz PLAYING a teacher, but NOT being teacher, touches on real life. Diaz and Justin Timberlake were a real-life couple for awhile. By juxtaposing a more manly man (Jason Segal, coach) with Timberlake, a very boy-like man, the viewer can easily surmise that Diaz needs a more manly man. In fact, her one "intimate" scene with Timberlake's substitute teacher character (substitute to the real thing), shows her boredom. It's that universal truism of a woman not knowing which man is really not good for her and which is. While Scarlet O'Hara did not get her man (at least, not in viewer or reader sight), Diaz's character does and we know it. By movie's end, when the viewer learns this, Diaz's character actually seems tamed, more womanly, instead of this unpredictable, wild force of nature.

One of the teaching issues made clear is that children need a steadying force, even if it is a bit wild. The cactus she carries into her new room obviously symbolizes her prickly personality. Yet--a cactus endures, just as Diaz's character does. Also, a cactus can provide sustenance.

As for the unrealistic parts: Diaz shows movies EVERY day for weeks and no one checks on her classroom? No one observes a new teacher? Middle school students don't complain to parents? Parents don't complain to principals? Supposedly urban/ghetto schools have no structure and no discipline-top down. I've seen so many of that type of movie that I actually believe that's how those schools operate.

Given her nature and tendency to self-absorb, I still like the advice she gives to the weird, geek boy who follows the most popular girl around. On a field trip he proclaims his love for this girl right in front of EVERYONE. As if that move will impress a popular girl! Diaz's character tells him first, to lose the geek hat he always wears (a trapper John type) and to give it up because the girl will NEVER EVER like him. Why so blunt? Because "I was that girl--empty, shallow" and interested only in those like her. Cruel? Maybe? Blunt? Oh, definitely, but information worthy. Move on with your life. It was great advice.

Because she wants to buy a pair of big "ti__ies", Diaz's character tries a number of money making projects, including inserting herself in a school car wash. She becomes a wet t-shirt, shorts, legs, everything and makes plenty. Are we supposed to believe that teachers really do these things? Maybe, but with a grain of salt. After all, she represents "bad teachers."

Academy Award material. Nope, not the film. Disgusting? Not really. Funny! Yes, I laughed out loud and it felt good! This is a comedy I will see again one day. That in itself is a pretty good recommendation! As for Diaz herself, she plays her character full-throttle. An Academy for Diaz? Probably not, as most awards go to actors playing exceptional, down-trodden characters. An award for a "bad teacher"? Wild things sometimes happen....

2011 has been an above-average year for female-driven comedy, with recent films like "Bridesmaids", and "What's Your Number", proving to be the good and the bad. Today, we have "Bad Teacher", a Cameron Diaz film that falls somewhere in the middle of that spectrum.

It follows Elizabeth Halsey, a morally corrupt middle-school English teacher, whose plans to quit her day job, to be a kept woman, were derailed. She's not necessarily a bad person, in my eyes, but she really shouldn't be teaching. She drinks, smokes weed, and puts on movies for her class, on the first day of school. She plays films for her class about good teachers, like "Dead Poets Society" and "Freedom Writers", while she pours airplane bottles of vodka into her coffee mug, ignoring her students completely.

All of this is very funny to me, because this part of the movie is pretty well-conceived. Cameron Diaz gave a great performance, and proved herself to have above-average comic timing. She isn't to blame for where "Bad Teacher" went wrong. It leaves this viewer underwhelmed, at a film that should have been a lot funnier. However, it isn't necessarily a bad movie either. It's just never as funny as it should be.

Written by "The Office" alums Lee Eisenberg and Gene Stupnitsky, the film slightly resembles a long episode of "The Office" - something that has a brilliant concept, and the fully capable actors, however, it never really comes together in the end. However, there are a lot of reasons why this movie did work.

One being that it makes pretty good use of the time that it's given. It runs about 90 minutes, on the dot, and it feels full and decently conceived. One big reason is Cameron Diaz, proving herself not to be just a pretty face, but something of a cunning comedienne. She plays one of the most detestable characters that American cinema has recently seen, however, the audience can't help but root for her.

However, when the movie approaches moments of golden politically incorrect humor every so often, it's not what it should have been. A standard has been set for R-rated comedy films in the past few years, by films like "Knocked Up", "The Hangover" and "Bridesmaids", showing that there's a new point-of-no-return for comedy. This involves raunchy humor, yet it proves every so often, that new comedic punchlines and ideas haven't run dry.

However, "Bad Teacher" shows us nothing we haven't seen before, recycling jokes from other (and better) movies. From a lame school car-wash scene, to a borderline degrading subplot about a boob job, there isn't enough good to outweigh the bad. As I said, it has its moments, but there aren't enough of those moments to make this a great film.

Grade: B-

BAD TEACHER is a mixed bag.  [Possible SPOILERS AHEAD]

Diaz plays Elizabeth  Halsey, a ruthless, wildly inappropriate middle school teacher who doesn't give a damn about her students or colleagues, and "teaches" by showing her class movies while she sleeps off the previous night's drunk.

Why wasn't this woman was fired months ago?

After her wealthy fianc and his mother dump her, Elizabeth is out to snag another rich husband and she sets her sights on a new substitute teacher (Justin Timberlake) who comes from money.  Unfortunately for her, Justin is more attracted to Elizabeth's chief rival (Lucy Punch), a triangle that leads to a "war" between the two women...neither of which we, as an audience, are rooting for.

Certainly there are moments in this picture that one cannot help but laugh at Elizabeth's outrageous remarks, but these awkward laughs are akin to the somewhat incredulous guffaws we give Larry David and his inappropriate actions on CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM.

Elizabeth may "soften" late in the picture, but she certainly doesn't change and nothing in the screenplay by Gene Stupnitsky & Lee Eisenberg really justifies her "winning" at the film's end.

Phyllis Smith, John Michael Higgins and Jason Segel co-star in the movie, directed by Jake Kasdan.

Extras on the DVD, which contains both the theatrical and unrated versions of the movie, include deleted scenes, outtakes and two "Behind the Scenes" featurettes.

Hollywood has often elicited laughs from broad characterizations of teachers who would never last two days in public education.  "Bad Teacher" is just such a movie.  Elizabeth Halsey (Cameron Diaz) has just completed her first (and what she hopes is her last) year of teaching at John Adams Middle School.  Engaged to a rich man, she anticipates a married life of luxury.

 However, he dumps her and she's back teaching in the fall.  Hardly the dedicated, hardworking educator, Elizabeth goes through the motions, doing as little as possible in the classroom.  Her new goal:  saving enough money for breast augmentation surgery.  This will be her bait for wealthy guys, she hopes.  The film focuses on the ways and means Elizabeth employs -- mostly unethical -- to raise the cash for her operation.

 When she discovers that a new substitute teacher, Mr. Delacorte (Justin Timberlake), is from a monied family, she sets her sights on him, but finds she has some competition in the person of fellow teacher Amy Squirrel (Lucy Punch).  Amy is the poster girl for Perfect Teacher.  She decorates her classroom zealously, uses clever motivational techniques, and dotes on bureaucratic rules and regulations.  She is the complete opposite of Elizabeth.

 Most of the laughs in this R-rated comedy come from Elizabeth's outrageous, politically incorrect classroom methodology.  She curses, smokes, comes to class hung over, dresses far too provocatively, and has no inkling of the names of the children in her class.  Because the comedy is so broad and over the top, it can be enjoyed as a spoof.  It is by no means an accurate portrayal of middle school teaching, nor does it intend to be.

 Ms. Diaz is captivating in an unsympathetic role.  Her sense of superiority, her open disdain for students and colleagues, and her lack of effort make her not merely a flake but a selfish, thoughtless bully.  Yet we watch her make her way awkwardly through the day-to-day tasks of educating young minds, performing one outlandish faux pas after another, whether aimed at kids' insecurities, parents' concern for the curriculum, standardized tests, or a principal (John Michael Higgins) who must balance teacher squabbling with oversight from the superintendent.

 The rest of the cast also deliver some spot-on performances in "Bad Teacher," which elevate it from merely OK to very good.  Ms. Punch is very funny as Amy, who starts out as a friend to Elizabeth and becomes her romantic rival.  Justin Timberlake is cast against type as a nerdy, bookish teacher who has recently had his heart broken.  Phyllis Smith (TV's "The Office") steals her scenes as Ms. Davies, a shy, middle-aged teacher who befriends Elizabeth and emerges from her shell somewhat as she learns how to have fun.  And Jason Segal plays phys ed teacher Russell Gettis, who is attracted by Elizabeth's considerable physical charms but put off by her behavior in school and the example she is setting for her kids.

 In "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," it develops that a popular, charismatic teacher is really a detriment to her students.  In "Bad Teacher," we know that going in.  The jokes emerge as we watch Elizabeth Halsey navigate the waters of public education through a boozy haze.  One thing is sure:  as you think back to your days in middle school, you'll be grateful you never had a teacher anywhere near as terrible as Ms. Halsey.

On the whole, I rate the film as follows:

ACTING: A
 -Diaz shines in this movie for, really, the first time in a while. Timberlake and Jason Segal each add the flare that we are accustomed to receiving when they film. The interactions between the characters are believable and each embodies the role cast to them.

PLOT: C

The problem with "Bad Teacher is that she simply isn't bad enough.

Elizabeth (Cameron Diaz) puts in her time as a teacher at a junior high school, all to prove to her sugar daddy fiance that she is the marrying type and not really a gold digging viper. But her future step-mother puts a stop to the wedding and Elizabeth returns to the school unready and bitter about having to teach her classes. The job is now necessary to provide a living, a very modest living. The first day back, she runs into the new substitute teacher, Scott (Justin Timberlake) and quickly learns he comes from a rich family and recently broke up with his buxom girlfriend. Elizabeth becomes convinced the way to Scott's heart is by getting a new, expensive boob job. Elizabeth desperately comes up with an assortment of ways to earn, scam and steal the money for the operation. Russell (Jason Segel), the gym teacher, shows some interest in her, but because he is a gym teacher, making a gym teacher's salary, she couldn't be less interested. But he continues to make overtures. Amy (Lucy Punch, the stalker in "Dinner With Schmucks") is a good teacher, who takes great pride in her job, so naturally she and Elizabeth develop an ongoing rivalry. Then, Elizabeth's friend, Lynn (Phyllis Smith, TV's "The Office") tells her about a teaching prize, a prize Amy has won every year. Elizabeth has a new goal.

"Bad Teacher", directed by Jake Kasdan ("Zero Effect", "Orange County") has a handful of laughs, but just as it seems to be fulfilling the promise of the concept, it starts to pull back, as though the filmmakers are afraid to push the envelope too far.

Diaz's portrayal of Elizabeth is basically a one-joke pony. The teacher is foul mouthed and doesn't seem to care who hears it. That's pretty much it. Occasionally, she does something that could be considered 'bad', but these moments simply don't go far enough. The problem is everything is too easy for her. Once she gets an idea, it goes according to her plan. The complications arise from the other people around her. But because these complications don't really present much of a roadblock, everything seems too easy for her. Imagine if Lucy Ricardo had found a job she was good at, a job to earn the money for her new hat, if Ricky had let her into the show, countless episodes of "I Love Lucy" wouldn't exist. "I Love Lucy" is such a timeless classic because Lucy has to work very hard to get to her goals and they are extremely funny because she almost always gets in her own way. "Bad Teacher" misses a lot of opportunities to be funny because she doesn't have to work hard enough, there aren't enough complications.

In fact, the funniest moments come from Amy Squirrel, the character played by Lucy Punch, because she can't convince anyone that Elizabeth is a terrible educator. And, because she is complaining so much, the focus begins to shift to her and we start to learn things about her.

Lucy Punch played easily the most unfunny and annoying character in "Dinner With Shmucks", her previous film. Which is saying a lot. Everyone in that film was annoying and unfunny. In ""Teacher", Amy has some vague similarities, but because her efforts are consistently thwarted by Elizabeth, she becomes desperate and a little funny. This goes on so long that everyone else starts to turn their attention towards Amy, dredging up her unwelcome history and turning a spotlight on her actions. And because of this, Amy becomes the funniest character in the film.

As Diaz is the star of the film, we want and need her to be the center of the story. She is the 'Bad Teacher'. She needs to be bad, to shock us. She sure has a foul mouth, but that is pretty much the extent of it. Maybe some people find this to be enough, but I don't. We need to see and hear more examples of how bad she is. If you are going to make an 'R' rated comedy called "Bad Teacher", really push the boundaries. Diaz and Kasdan don't do this.

The set-up for "Teacher" is funny. We quickly get why Elizabeth is a teacher, what she is trying to do and how she plans to accomplish it. But then everything in her life comes crashing down and we begin to learn a little bit more about Elizabeth. She is a truly desperate person and begins to come up with some ideas about how to get herself back on track.

Justin Timberlake plays Scott, the too-sweet, too-nave substitute teacher who captures Elizabeth's eye. She corners him and learns more about him. He could be the ticket to the Sweet Life. Initially, his "aw-shucks" navet is fun and so different from Elizabeth that we can't help but chuckle. And then he seems oblivious to the ongoing battle between Elizabeth and Amy, which is also amusing. But these ongoing situations only carry the humor so far. When nothing else is developed, the film dies quickly and resorts to the Timberlake staple; he starts singing an older song in a weird way. He has done this repeatedly, on "Saturday Night Live", in films, it even seems to be a part of his new film "Friends with Benefits". It was a funny idea the first few times. But it has now played out.

Jason Segel plays Russell, the gym teacher, and he also has a few good moments. When he initially makes a play for the bad teacher, he is quickly rebuffed. But this doesn't seem to faze him. Later, he does become miffed and decides to retaliate. Again, good for a few moments and then nothing happens.

This is the main problem for the entire film. All of the set-ups are good. For a few moments. But they don't evolve and take on new dimensions to continue to surprise us and entertain us.

"Horrible Bosses", released two weeks after "Teacher", would seem to be ripe for the same problems and criticisms. But "Bosses" delivers on the "Horrible" promise. Each of the three bosses is very bad, for very different reasons. And each of the three actors seems to relish and enjoy the chance to push the boundaries.

In "Teacher", Kasdan and Diaz seem to pull back, afraid of going to that darker place. And because of that, "Bad Teacher" doesn't just give an 'F', it gets a D.

And boy is this character nasty. She's greedy, she's lazy, and she's selfish. She lies, she steals, she manipulates. What's also interesting is that the storyline of the repugnant central character, Elizabeth, does not fall into either of the two clichs that you'd expect from a Hollywood film:

1) She does not end up finding herself inspired by the children and discover a love of teaching, revealing a heart of gold hidden beneath her prickly exterior.

2) She does not find herself getting her comeuppance for being such an awful human being.

If anything, the characters in the film who are depicted as truly pathetic are Elizabeth's sincere, hardworking fellow teachers. Is this a dubious message? Perhaps. But the performers are all so funny and likable (Lucy Punch and Justin Timberlake are both hilarious) that they manage to make up for the film's many flaws.

RELEASED IN 2011 and directed by Jake Kasdan, Bad Teacher is a dramedy about a slothful, inept middle school teacher in Illinois (Cameron Diaz) who hates her work, her pupils and her colleagues. She has no choice but to return to teaching after losing her sugar daddy and aspires to the lofty goal of getting breast implants. Lucy Punch plays her winsome rival while Justin Timberlake appears as a wealthy eligible teacher. Jason Segel plays the gym teacher whos interested in her while Phyllis Smith appears as her aged, overweight teacher pal.

Do you remember the bad teacher at your school? Every school has at least one, usually more. I found Bad Teacher amusing from beginning to end and occasionally laugh-out-loud funny. It helps that the characters are all well-defined & cast and that the story is absorbing. The soundtrack features some quality snippets by the likes of Judas Priest (Youve God Another Thing Coming & The Ripper), Whitesnake (Still of the Night) and Dio (Rainbow in the Dark).

NOTE: I saw the censored version, not the unrated one, which is likely gross.

THE MOVIE RUNS 1 hour & 32 minutes and was shot in Southern Cal (Los Angeles & Santa Clarita) with exterior shots done in Illinois (Springfield & Lawndale). WRITERS: Gene Stupnitsky & Lee Eisenberg. ADDITIONAL CAST: John Michael Higgins is on hand as the principle and Thomas Lennon as a school official.

GRADE: B+
